def.dt: :heated to the boiling point
:torrid a boiling sun
:intensely agitated a boiling sea boiling with anger
:to an extreme degree :very boiling mad boiling hot

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French buillir, boillir, from Latin bullire to bubble, from bulla bubble

def.dt: :to come to the boiling point
:to generate bubbles of vapor when heated used of a liquid
:to cook in boiling water
:to become agitated :seethe
:to be moved, excited, or stirred up
:to rush headlong
:to burst forth
:to undergo the action of a boiling liquid
:to subject to the action of a boiling liquid
:to heat to the boiling point
:to form or separate (as sugar or salt) by boiling
:the temperature at which a liquid boils
:the point at which a person becomes uncontrollably angry
:the point of crisis :head 17b matters had reached the boiling point
:to reduce in bulk by boiling
:condense summarize boil down a report
:to undergo reduction in bulk by boiling
:to be equivalent in summary :amount his speech boiled down to a plea for more money
:to reduce ultimately your choices boil down to three
:to overflow while boiling
:to become so incensed as to lose one's temper
:to cook (an egg) in the shell until both white and yolk have solidified
